awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Durable Omni-Phobic Coatings
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to provide environmentally friendly, self-cleaning coating technologies. Fluorinated materials, known as forever materials, have been widely used due to their excellent self-cleaning properties, but the detrimental environmental impacts resulting from these coatings motivate the introduction of environmentally friendly solutions. This project plans to create a new technology to enable environmentally-friendly coatings capable of adhering to a myriad of substrates under any conditions, while offering high abrasion resistance and exceptional weather resistance. The successful completion of the project will set the stage for commercialization and adoption of this technology for household and industrial products, automotive applications, sensors, solar panels, and aerospace applications.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to validate pilot-scale production feasibility, enhance the weatherability, and enable the commercialization of fluorine-free, self-cleaning materials. Previous approaches toward self-cleaning coatings have had several limitations such as reliance on harmful fluorochemicals, high cost, poor scalability, poor optical properties, and low weatherability. The proposed technology is developed via a unique approach that enables higher performance, fluorine-free coatings (e.g., excellent mechanical properties, optical clarity, hydrophobicity, adhesion) while preserving the ease of manufacturing processes at a lower cost. The key objectives of this proposed project include: 1) pilot-scale production of the coating to set the stage for commercialization; 2) extend the weatherability for high-end applications such as those in the automotive and aerospace sectors; and 3) develop protocols for omniphobic additives for rapid implementation of the technology into  relevant applications. The anticipated results include successful pilot-scale production tests, accomplishing the long-term weatherability, and the successful synthesis of omniphobic additives with desirable compositions and performance. The successful completion of the project will set the stage for commercialization and adoption of this technology for household and industrial products, automotive applications, sensors, solar panels, and aerospace, to name a few.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Project: Durable Omni-Phobic Coatings That Will Replace Environmentally Problematic Fluorinated Coatings

Director/PI: Md Golam Sarwar

Federal Award ID: 2136419

 

For this project, SCOPS Coatings aimed to create cost-competitive, durable and nonfluorinated omniphobic coating products to replace environmentally problematic coatings containing PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances). Commercial coatings are used across a wide spectrum of products to achieve durability, scratch resistance, UV protection, eased cleaning and a glossy appearance. Depending on the formulation, such coatings can also provide functional barriers to water (hydrophobic), staining and grease (oleophobic). A multitude of industries use coatings with one or more functional barrier properties (in other words, omniphobic) in automotive, architectural, aerospace, marine, medical device, mining, textile, clinical diagnostic, sensor and packaging applications.

Unfortunately, most hydrophobic and oleophobic coatings in the market today are PFAS-based. A group of over 5,000 synthetic chemicals that are believed to be a threat to human health and the environment, PFAS nevertheless provides cost-effective and exceptional product performance.  As more countries move to ban PFAS-containing products, the demand for safe and sustainable alternatives continues to grow. Yet, parties have struggled to develop adequate PFAS-free alternatives. Many PFAS-free omniphobic coatings and additives face issues, including but not limited to: 1) reduced optical clarity, 2) insufficient durability and adhesion, leading to diminished omniphobic properties over time, and 3) cost structures that hinder commercial adoption.

SCOPS Coatings focused its efforts on the development of a PFAS-free omniphobic polyurethane additive to coat glass (such as automotive or architectural) and a wide array of building products. This additive, derived from innovative chemistry developed at Michigan State University, was believed to overcome the array of limitations in PFAS-free coatings, and would cause water to bead, would slough off dirt, grease, graffiti and would resist damage from the sun and other elements.

SCOPS Coatings successfully developed and extensively tested additives that met all of these criteria. Even more significant, these groundbreaking products can be added to most any polyurethane formulation, allowing ready deployment across a multitude of industries and applications.

Not only did SCOPS innovate such an effective polyurethane additive, it also solved for well-known issues with adhering coatings to glass, ceramic and metal. The challenge of adhering a non-polar coating to a polar substrate is often addressed with primers or additional additives, but with varying success. Through our rigorous water bath adhesion tests, we found that where commercial primers failed, our novel adhesion promoters exceeded the success criteria.  Furthermore, the master batch system we developed allows us to produce stable coating materials that are easy to transport and can be mixed onsite as needed, significantly reducing expense. All in all, SCOPS successfully developed an effective PFAS-free water- and grease-repellent additive for polyurethane, with performance on par with or superior to existing PFAS-based products.

In the course of our relationship with Michigan State University, SCOPS learned that one of the most immediate and voluminous needs for PFAS-free, omniphobic coatings was in the area of packaging, particularly for quick-serve restaurants, food processors and consumer goods (CPG) manufacturers. These highly price sensitive industries have long relied on PFAS additives to paper, and fiberboard to contain moisture and grease during transport, storage and use. We are optimistic that there are meaningful opportunities to extend the innovations from this project to applications in the packaging industry.

We are proud that two laboratory bench scientists at the non-PhD level were hired to support SBIR and sponsored research activities. They received mentorship from Principal Investigator Dr. Mohammed Golam Sarwar and Senior Scientist Dr. John Walls, both of whom possess extensive technical knowledge in coatings. These mentors continue to provide training in organic chemistry testing techniques and standard laboratory practices that are not typically learned in the classroom. This hands-on coaching in an industry setting has proven invaluable to both SCOPS Coatings and its team members.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2024
Modified by: Md G Sarwar

Project Outcomes Report

Federal Award ID: 2136419





For this project, SCOPS Coatings aimed to create cost-competitive, durable and nonfluorinated omniphobic coating products to replace environmentally problematic coatings containing PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances).
